He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. Dear Recruiters, please stop this."We're hiring freshers!"Great. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. Dear Recruiters, please stop this."We're hiring freshers!"Great. A golden chance, right?Then comes 3 rounds of interviews, hours of preparation, days of hope.And finally:"Sorry, we're looking for someone with at least 1 year of experience."But why call a fresher in the first place?Their resume clearly said "Fresher."You saw it.You still scheduled them.You still made them prep.You still gave them hope.➡Time wasted➡Mental bandwidth drained➡Confidence shakenPlease understand: for freshers, every opportunity is huge.Every interview is a big deal.Don’t treat it casually.If you're not genuinely hiring fresh talent, please don’t advertise that you are.Don’t fake opportunities.Don’t play with emotions.Don’t contribute to burnout.Be honest. Be fair. Be human.That's the least we ask.Follow Dr Vishal Pandey 🇮🇳

He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. Dear Recruiters, please stop this."We're hiring freshers!"Great. A golden chance, right?Then comes 3 rounds of interviews, hours of preparation, days of hope.And finally:"Sorry, we're looking for someone with at least 1 year of experience."But why call a fresher in the first place?Their resume clearly said "Fresher."You saw it.You still scheduled them.You still made them prep.You still gave them hope.➡Time wasted➡Mental bandwidth drained➡Confidence shakenPlease understand: for freshers, every opportunity is huge.Every interview is a big deal.Don’t treat it casually.If you're not genuinely hiring fresh talent, please don’t advertise that you are.Don’t fake opportunities.Don’t play with emotions.Don’t contribute to burnout.Be honest. Be fair. Be human.That's the least we ask.Follow Dr Vishal Pandey 🇮🇳

He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. He made the jump from Samsung India (13.5 LPA) to Google (50 LPA) within just 2 years of graduating and cracked 4 offers from (Amazon, Google, ION Trading, Lime Road) in the worst job market possible. While companies have been laying off people consistently, what magic did Vaibhav did to get 4 offers in 2024 and that too while working full time at Samsung? Here's his strategy: (DSA + Time Management + Overall Job Hunting Mindset) ➧ Never stopped DSA, no matter what.→ Started with just C in college, then moved to C++ and DSA by second year.→ Solved 900+ DSA questions in college. Crossed 1,500 before landing Google.→ Didn’t try to do everything: stuck to LeetCode, Codeforces, and GFG. No jumping to every new platform.→ Built a daily habit. Even during the toughest office days, DSA didn’t stop.--Also, If you’re learning DSA currently, enrollments in my DSA cohort are still open.- added access to LLD module- community of 100s of students- 5 exclusive sessions with FAANG recruiters & engineersCheck it out here:https://lnkd.in/gJQZWGeh--➧ Job + Preparation: Managed Both (even with a 3.5-hour daily commute!)→ Samsung office shift: 8.5 hours/day. Commute: 3.5 hours/day. Still made time.→ After reaching home at 7pm, took a break, then sat down at 8:30pm every night, 2 hours for DSA, 30-45 min for job applications.→ Saturday/Sunday: 4-5 hours straight for DSA, system design, and interview prep. Treated weekends as “bonus time” for deep focus.➧ Didn’t just send 10 resumes and chill, Applied Everywhere (with a system)→ Applied to more than 2,000 jobs in 1–1.5 years. For Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe: 30-40 times each.→ Used Naukri, LinkedIn (sorted by “recent jobs”), and company career pages directly.→ Kept Naukri profile “active” by making small updates daily, this actually increased HR calls.→ Bought LinkedIn Premium, used “actively hiring” filter, messaged HRs with a direct note (job ID + resume + why he fits).➧ Referrals are not magic, Direct Applications Worked→ Out of all his offers, referrals only got him a Google interview. For the rest, direct application did the job.→ For referrals, sent short, direct messages to employees: “Here’s my background, here’s the job, here’s why I fit.”→ No spamming; targeted each message to the right person.➧ Resume: Only What Matters, No “Gyaan”→ For freshers: Projects should be unique, not just “Netflix Clone”. Wrote exactly what he built, not a copied template.→ For experienced: Wrote clear numbers (“improved speed by X%”), not just feature lists.→ Made resume on Overleaf (LaTeX) for clean, ATS-friendly formatting.Continued in Comments ↡

Dear Recruiters, Hiring Managers, and Current Employees,Providing opportunities and guidance is essential for every fresher starting their career . My request to everyone give a chance to speak with you and present our experiences and achievements .To current employees when a job seeker  takes the time to reach out with a detailed message, a simple response, even if it’s just a polite acknowledgment or a “yes” or “no,” would be greatly appreciated.Job seekers are not only searching for opportunities they are also looking for encouragement, hope, and someone who believes in them.my name is  Hema, and I’m a Data Engineer with over 4+  years of experience specializing in cloud-based data engineering solutions using Azure, Databricks, PySpark, Python, and SQL. I’ve worked extensively on end-to-end data pipeline implementation using Azure Data Factory, Synapse Analytics, and Delta Lake on Databricks. I’ve developed and maintained scalable ELT workflows, integrated structured and semi-structured data from multiple sources, and supported real-time and batch data processing use cases.One of my core strengths lies in large-scale data migrations and modernizing legacy systems to the cloud. I’ve led efforts in conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, ensuring data quality, performance, and governance through CI/CD and reusable frameworks.I have domain experience in healthcare, banking, and financial services, where I worked closely with cross-functional teams to develop analytical datasets that drive business decisions and predictive models. For example, in a recent healthcare project, I automated the ingestion and transformation of EMR data using Databricks notebooks and improved data availability by 60%.In addition to my technical skills, I’m confident working in agile environments with global delivery teams, and I prioritize clear communication and documentation. I’m also comfortable with Unix shell scripting, version control via Git, and I hold a Databricks/AWS/SNOWFLAKE  Certified Data Engineer Associate certification. Overall, I’m passionate about building clean, reliable, and scalable data solutions that help businesses gain insights and deliver measurable value.I'm currently seeking a full-time Data Engineering role where I can apply my skills to solve real world data challenges and contribute to impactful, scalable solutions.Please feel free to connect, message me, or reach out at edavalapatihema13@gmail.com if you're hiring or know of relevant opportunities. Dear Recruiters, please stop this."We're hiring freshers!"Great. A golden chance, right?Then comes 3 rounds of interviews, hours of preparation, days of hope.And finally:"Sorry, we're looking for someone with at least 1 year of experience."But why call a fresher in the first place?Their resume clearly said "Fresher."You saw it.You still scheduled them.You still made them prep.You still gave them hope.➡Time wasted➡Mental bandwidth drained➡Confidence shakenPlease understand: for freshers, every opportunity is huge.Every interview is a big deal.Don’t treat it casually.If you're not genuinely hiring fresh talent, please don’t advertise that you are.Don’t fake opportunities.Don’t play with emotions.Don’t contribute to burnout.Be honest. Be fair. Be human.That's the least we ask.Follow Dr Vishal Pandey 🇮🇳
